photo.description: Many artists have called Key West, Florida, home including Ernest Hemingway. His cats' offspring still prowl the grounds looking for mice.
photo.tags: key west florida fl usa ernesthemingway travel
photo.title: Ernest Hemingway's Home

photo.description: Local call number: DM0159 Title: Cat relaxing in front of the Hemingway House: Key West, Florida Date: September 1993 General note: The Ernest Hemingway Home & Museum, located at 907 Whitehead Street in Key West, was built in 1851 by marine architect and salvage wrecker Asa Tift. Hemingway purchased the property in 1931 and furnished the home with furniture and dÃ©cor collected during his world travels. The house is also home to several six-toed cats, descendants of those living during the Hemingway's time. Today, visitors can tour the grounds of the Hemingway house, including the author's writing room, and meet its now famous feline residents. Physical descrip: 1 slide - col. Series Title: Dale M. McDonald Collection Repository: State Library and Archives of Florida, 500 S. Bronough St., Tallahassee, FL 32399-0250 USA. Contact: 850.245.6700. Archives@dos.state.fl.us Persistent URL: www.floridamemory.com/items/show/97510

photo.description: Courtesy of a mutated predecessor, quite a few of Hemingway's cats are polydactyl (many-toed). The original cat was a gift to Hemingway from a friend of his - she bred, and those litters bred. The Hemingway house aims to hold about sixty, with the numbers controlled through spaying. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".
photo.tags: 020511 florida keywest ernesthemingway hemingwayhouse polydactylcat polydactyl cat feline hemingwaycat ernesthemingwayhomeandmuseum
photo.title: Cat's Paw

photo.description: A shade too dark, but it shows the writer's creative den. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.description: A lamp with a pineapple design. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.description: French chandeliers installed in the house by Pauline Hemingway - these replaced the original ceiling fans and, as the guide commented, "Every day I look at those chandeliers and think of Pauline". photo.description: The swimming pool is 65 feet long and 9 feet deep at one end. It was built during the winter of 1937-38 and cost $20,000.00. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.description: Courtesy of a mutated predecessor, quite a few of Hemingway's cats are polydactyl (many-toed). The original cat was a gift to Hemingway from a friend of his - she bred, and those litters bred. The Hemingway house aims to hold about sixty, with the numbers controlled through spaying. Not really obvious here, but this cat was busy playing with a lizard. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.description: This is a modern replica of the original - a cat ceramic made by Pablo Picasso. The original was stolen by a thief and broken when he was apprehended shortly after. This reproduction was made by local artist, Bob Orlin. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".
photo.tags: 020511 florida keywest ernesthemingway hemingwayhouse ernesthemingwayhomeandmuseum
photo.title: Iron Guttering

photo.description: A ceramic pachyderm, looking into the swimming pool. The swimming pool is 65 feet long and 9 feet deep at one end. It was built during the winter of 1937-38 and cost $20,000.00. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".
photo.tags: 020511 florida keywest ernesthemingway hemingwayhouse ernesthemingwayhomeandmuseum
photo.title: Pool Elephant

photo.description: Close-up detail. The house's first owner, Asa Tift, had this raised flowerbed and pond built in the shape of an ironclad from the American Civil War. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.title: Ironclad

photo.description: The top of the fountain is an old Spanish olive jar from Cuba, but the trough is the interesting thing. This came from "Sloppy Joe's" (Hemingway's drinking haunt) and was originally a urinal. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".
photo.tags: 020511 florida keywest ernesthemingway hemingwayhouse ernesthemingwayhomeandmuseum
photo.title: Cat Fountain

photo.description: Courtesy of a mutated predecessor, quite a few of Hemingway's cats are polydactyl (many-toed). The original cat was a gift to Hemingway from a friend of his - she bred, and those litters bred. The Hemingway house aims to hold about sixty, with the numbers controlled through spaying. The house was built by Asa Tift, a marine architect (and Confederate mariner), in 1851. In 1931 Hemingway purchased it and lived here with his second wife, Pauline, and their two sons until 1939. Here, Hemingway completed the final draft of "A Farewell to Arms," as well as "The Snows of Kilimanjaro" and "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber".

photo.description: French chandeliers installed in the house by Pauline Hemingway - these replaced the original ceiling fans and, as the guide commented, "Every day I look at those chandeliers and think of Pauline".
